Barnes And Noble Acquires

BY ROBERT INSOFT
As a result of new contract
proposals from several other
companies and complaints by
both students and faculty, the
University has decided not to
extend the current contract with
Follett's and has chosen Barnes
and Noble to manage the campus bookstore.
Director of Auxiliary Services Bettye Miller explained
that before the expiration of the
Follett's present contract--which
expired December 31--the school
began taking bids from other
companies wanting to operate
the
Homewood
bookstore.
Several companies, including
Follett's, were sent proposals
outlining the University's needs.
"It was time to look and see
what was out there," Miller said,
noting that more than 10 years
had gone by since the University

had last changed contractors.
Last year, as proposals were
being reviewed, a committee-composed of faculty, administration, and students—was established_ to review Follett's past
service. Among students' complaints were Follett's poor sales
return policies and lack of used
textbooks. Also, many faculty.
members and graduate students
expressed the need for more
"tradebooks" to supplement
course reading lists, and additional research materials.
After careful review of all
seven prospective companies, the
field was narrowed to four, then
Dean of Academic Services Jakie
Hall made the final decision to
choose Barnes and Noble. Miller
explained that an important
factor in the decision was the
firm's service record in more
than 25 other universities, including Cornell, Columbia, and

desire to run a "qualified bookstore," Barnes and Noble was
the only other company that

Council Committee Chooses
Topic For MSE Symposium
"America and the Immigrant Experience" has been
chosen as the topic of the 1981
Milton S. Eisenhower Symposium. The winning proposal,
submitted by Vinay Lal, Tobias
Steed, and Rohit Bhatnagar, will
explore the motivations, experiences, and impact of immigrants
to the United States.
The symposium will deal

not only with immigrants to
America from an historical perspective, but will also consider
more contemporary issues such
as the recent Cuban refugee
exodus and the migration of
blacks from the urban areas of
the Northeast to the South and
West.
The 1981 MSE Symposium
will differ in some ways from

previous years. Lal, Steed, and
Bhatnagar have proposed twelve
topics to be covered instead of
the usual ten. They have also
proposed a Symposium first: a
debate between scholars, who
will discuss the advantages of
immigrants completely assimilating themselves to American
culture.

Safehouse Sponsors Fundraiser
BY JEAN PRESTON
A network of homes where
women can go if they are being
followed or have been attacked
will soon be organized by a
group of women who live in the
Charles Village-Waverly area.
Neighborhood volunteers will
post illuminated green signs in
their windows bearing the logo
of the project, a woman's sign
with a house inside. "When that
light is on, that's a sign that a
safehouse is operating," explained one of the women
involved in the program.
Participants will "know what
to do when a woman comes to

their door needing help." Instruction in handling emergencies will include first aid, selfdefense, and information referral. The training will take place
at two orientation sessions, a
short meeting Thursday, March
26 and a longer seminar Sunday,
April 5.
The Baltimore Safehouse Project is an outgrowth of a similar
program begun in Cambridge,
Mass. in response to a rising
crime rate and fear of attacks.
The subject was discussed last
July at a conference, "On
Against Women,"
Violence
sponsored by the Women's
Union of Baltimore.
According to Ronnie Weiss,

one of the project's organizers,
the program is "primarily geared
to help women help themselves.
Men are welcome to participate
so long as a woman is part of the
household."
Safehouse is holding a fundraiser ($2.00 donation) March
13 at St. Johns Church, 27th
and St. Paul Sts., starting at 8:30
p.m. The benefit will include
folksinging and a skit. Recorded
dance music will be provided by
Glenn Bernie. Donations will go
toward paper and light bulbs for
the signs.
For more information on the
group or the event, contact
366-7559 or 366-4228.

What Is JHU, Really?
BY LINDSAY KAPLAN
Undergraduates spend a lot
of time analyzing challenging
and criticizing institutions, issues
and each other; this process is
loosely referred to as an Education.
The Education itself
is often the object of this
examination. Students can be
heard complaining about various
aspects of this nebulous phenomenon, ranging from the pithy
favorite, "College Sucks," to
move thoughtful comments on
the quality, breadth and usefulness of an undergraduate
education.
The idea of an undergraduate education at Hopkins . is

particularly problematic because
the University was initially conceived of as a graduate institution. Even in the misty realm of
education one finds that distinctions between graduate and
undergraduate learning have
been made. Graduate students
are expected to be fairly independent, motivated and capable
of formulating their own ideas.
Conversely, undergraduate students are conceived of as dependent quasi-adolescents who require support in fashioning their
thoughts and encouragement
(read: regimentation) in their
studies.

therefore, that the type of

An Oddly Human Document
What are intentions worth?
The Judicial Code is an oddly human
document: it is full of contradictions,
flaws, and outright blunders; it has, underneath its semantic problems, a very wellintentioned drive to create some workable
system; and most important, its strengths
and weaknesses came from an ongoing
process of change.
Among its many shortcomings:
The people involved in a case can't
bring a lawyer with them when they appear
to argue the case. This guarantees a superior position for the University,which retains
its right to a lawyer.
The boundaries of "sexual misconduct" are left undefined. We're all out of
here, pronto, if someone gets conservative
with this one. Why not just say rape,
assault, and flashing?
The Student Council, which would
choose Judicial Board members and exercise veto power, would maintain de facto
control over the board. A fair board is an
independent board. Obviously, someone
has to hold elections to begin with, but
after that, a Judicial Board runs its own
shop.
Improvements to the Code can only
come as amendents. There is no way to
revise the Code's many examples of vague

language before it undergoes a review--in
the fall of 1985.
And so on. But beyond its problems
lies a very basic plus: we finally have a
document that provides for due process.
The acid test, then:- So what if we
don't have a Judicial Code?
Eventually, we should work out a
method of stopping the arbitrary way discipline is meted out. The Judicial Code gives
students a say in the works, which is
lacking today. We believe, then, that
passing the document and then working on
its flaws is better than simply killing the
Code.
Mike Steele's opinion is that the
Code cannot be revised, and presented for a
second vote, and presented to the Board of
Trustees before the year is out should the
Code be defeated Tuesday. Why not work
around the red tape by passing the Code
and continuing to work on it?

threatened the life or safety of another person, as well as allegations of_gudent
misconduct during the summer months, shall be the sole responsibility of the
Dean of the Homewood Faculties or his designee.
The judicial code is to be in effect during the spring and fall academic
semesters as well as the intersession mini-semester and is to be jointly
administered by the Judicial Board of the Student Council and the Director of
Student Services [herinafter "Director"1. The Judicial Code provides the sole
Univeristy forums for airing disputes over which the Code has jurisdiction.
III. PROCEDURE
A. Procedure for certifying a charge:
1. Any person who believes that conduct warranting disciplinary action
has been committed by a student may file a written complaint
against the student with the Director of Student Activities, or his
designess.
2. A written complaint must be submitted within either:
a. fifteen (15) calendar days from the date of the commission of the
alleged offense, or
b. Fifteen (15) calendar days from the date of discovery of the
alleged offense or the identity of the offender.
3. The complaint must contain the following informationa. name and address of the complainant
b. name of the student(s) charged with misconduct
c. a specific and factual statement of the misconduct, including a
description of the damage or injury.
4. The Director shall mail or deliver notification to a student against
whom a charge has been made within three (3)calendar days
following the date of receipt of the complaint.
5. Notice must be served by either:
a. hand delivery, or
b. certified mail, return receipt requested.
6. Notice shall containa. a copy of the complaint including the name of the complainant;
b. copies of documentary evidence supporting the charge, if any. If
any new documentary evidence is obtained after notice is served
but prior to the hearing, a copy shall be given promptly to the
student charged, but no less than 72 hours before the hearing;
c. a copy of the judicial code;
d. notice that all parties have a right to an advisor who is a member
. of the University community to assist in the preparation of the
case, but an attorney may not represent either the complainant
or the student charged in proceedings under this Code;
e. time, date and place of a scheduled hearing to consider the
complaint.
7. Objections to jurisdiction over offenses may be submitted to the
Director. If the Director determines the offense is not one which
falls within the code's jurisdiction he shall terminate the matter and
inform both parties.
8. The Judicial Board shall maintain a log of complaints, chronologically numbered but lacking personal identifying information, with
information as to whether the conduct giving rise to the complaint
was considered as within the ambit of this code and the jurisdiction
of the Judicial Board.
9. The accused shall have the option to have his case heard before the
Judicial Board or the Director. If the student charged selects the
Judicial Board to hear his case, the Director shall convene the board.
IV. PROCEDURE FOR HEARING THE CASE BEFORE THE DIRECTOR
A. If the student charged selects the Director to hear the case, then the
following procedures shall be followed1 The hearing shall be closed unless the accused files a written request
for a public hearing with the Director. In cases of sexual misconduct the hearing shall be closed unless the accused files a written
request for a public hearing with the Director and the complainant
makes no objection. The complainant shall be notified as to
whether a hearing is to be closed or open.
2. All hearings shall be taped and both parties will be given access to
the tape upon request.
3. At the commencement of a hearing the Director shall read the
charges after which time the student shall indicate whether he
admits or denies the charge.
4. The Director shall receive all evidence and hear all testimony of the
parties and the witnesses at a hearing at which the complainant shall

the student charged shall be given an opportunity to rebut the complaint or present evidence of mitigating circumstances.
The Director and the parties shall have the opportunity to question
all witnesses.
The Director shall render a decision after hearing all evidence offered
by the parties.
The Director shall notify the parties of his decision either:
a. At the close of the hearing, to be subsequently confirmed in
writing, or
b. By letter within 7 calendar days following the date of the hearing.
The Director shall notify the Dean of Academic Services of the

The Director may recommend sanctions tothe Dean of Academic

V. PROCEDURE FOR CASES BEFORE THE JUDICIAL BOARD
A. The membership of the Board
1. Nine members will be selected by the Student Council, normally
during the previous academic year, according to the selection process
for the Student Council committees. Members shall serve one year
and may be reappointed.
2. The Student Council shall select students to fill vacancies on the
Board according to V.A.1.
3. The Board shall select a chairperson from among its members.
B. Composition of the Hearing Panel
1. The Chair shall prepare a list of Judicial Board members at the
beginning of the academic year.
2. A Hearing Panel shall be convened by selecting the first three names
on the list. The Presiding Official shall be the next person onthe list.
Every member of the Panel, including the Presiding Official, should
be free of bias or personal interest in the matter.
a. A member of the Panel, the student charged, or the complainant
may challenge the impartiality of a member.
b. The Panel shall hear the charges of bias and must decide whether
the voting member whould retain his seat. A majority of voting
members of the panel may remove a fellow member on the basis
of bias. The member challenged shall recuse himself from voting
on his disqualification. The Presiding Officer shall vote on the
question of bias. A new member shall be appointed to replace a
disqualified member.
3. The Presiding Official is to perform the following duties:
a. attend all Hearing Panel hearings
b. maintain all Judicial Board records and deliver the same to the
office of the General Counsel when not in use by the Judicial
Board.
c. vote only in the absence of a Panel member.
4. A member of the Judicial Board may be removed for dereliction of
duty by an affirmative vote of 6 members of the Judicial Board or
by a 2/3 vote of the Student Council.
5. A new Panel, consisting of the following six names will be convened
for each case.
C. Procedures for the Hearing Panel
1. The hearing shall be closed unless the accused files a written request
for a public hearing with the Director. In cases of sexual misconduct the hearing shall be closed unless the acccused files a written
request for a public hearing with the Director and the complainant
makes no objection. The complainant must be notified as to
whether a hearing is to be open or closed.
2. A.. hearings shall be taped and a party will be given access to the
tape upon request.
3. Security of the documentary evidence and any reports of the Hearing Panel shall be the responsibility of the Presiding Official or
his/her designee. The materials are to be kept in the Office of the
General Counsel.
4. The Presiding Official shall read the charges at the commencement
of the hearing and the student charged shall indicate whether he
admits or denies the charge.
5. The Panel shall receive all evidence and hear all testimony of the
parties and their witnesses at a hearing. The complainant shall first
present his complaint and supporting evidence and the student
charged shall then be given an opportunity to rebut the complaint
or present evidence of mitigating circumstances.
6. Panel members and the parties shall have the opportunity to
examine all the witnesses.
7. Members of the Hearing Panel shall not discuss the cases with persons not on the Panel.
8. The student charged may be found guilty by a unanimous vote. The
verdict shall be accompanied by a written opinion stating the basis
for the decision reached by the Panel and any dissenting opinion.
The entire record shall be forwarded to the Dean of Academic
Services.
VI. SANCTIONS
A. The Dean of Academic Services is responsible for determining and
implementing the sanction and shall meet with the student to be
disciplined before choosing a sanction. All sanctions shall reflect the
severity of the offense. The Dean is urged to take into consideration
the sanctions recommended by the Hearing Panel or the Director of
Student Activities.

Amendments to this Judicial Code shall be approved by a three quarters

Student Council and the Dean of Academic Services and a report shall
be presented to the Student Council no later than the beginning of the

In the event of a reorganization of the administration of the Homewood
faculties the references to any particular University academic or administrative office or officer shall be construed as referring to a successor office or
officer as bearing equivalent or substantially similar responsibilities, to be
determined by the chief academic officer of the University.

The Judicial Board is an independent committee of the Student Council.
The Student Council may not interfere with the activities or decisions of
the Judicial Board.

A failure to abide by the procedures established by this Code shall constitute a basis for an appeal.

has its "eating clubs," Harvard has its yard, and Johns
Hopkins has lacrosse and the official Lacrosse Hall of
Fame on its campus.
The 35 national lacrosse championships won by
the Blue Jays demonstrate their domination of the sport.
Twice lacrosse has been played in the Olympics (1928
and 1932) and each time the U.S. representative was
Johns Hopkins. Moreover, one quarter of those inducted into the Lacrosse Hall of Fame have been associated with Hopkins.
For Blue Jay sports fans, THE SEASON has
arrived. Pavlov would have felt at home at Hopkins,
since any Hoppie worth his weight in GPA points has
been conditioned to flee the confines of the Eisenhower
library for the excitement of Homewood Field. On a
typical Saturday afternoon in the spring, enough Hopkins students descend upon the Conrad Geblein stands
to make the untrained observer think that Organic and
Occ. Civ. review sessions are now being taught outside.
When the Blue Jays defeated Maryland to win
the NCAA championship in 1974 and 1979, the Hopkins
rooters sang "Amen"--presumably to mock the Terrapin
fans who traditionally sing it in victory. Lacrosse
disciples know better, however. They are convinced that
it was done to show that lacrosse is akin to religion at
Hopkins!
At Johns Hopkins, which considers itself the
center of the lacrosse world, national titles are expected
by everyone. Blue Jay coaches do not celebrate when
they win a championship; instead they breathe a sigh of
relief.
According to athletic director Bob Scott,
"Lacrosse is a fast-moving and exciting sport. The
wide-open action presents many scoring opportunities
during the course of a game. Fifteen to twenty-five
goals are commonly scored, and in my view lacrosse
contains the best elements of football, basketball,
soccer, and hockey."
The fastest game on two feet (hockey is played
on skates), lacrosse is an exciting and invigorating game
which is fun to watch and to play. At its best, the sport
combines the body contact of Stanley Cup hockey with
the agility, grace, and quickness of NBA basketball.

Bob Ott, a former star midfielder at Maryland,
called lacrosse "a jumble of all games. I enjoy the
violence like football. There is plenty of free running
like soccer. The play around the goal is much like
basketball, and the stick makes it like hockey."
Lacrosse was invented by North American
Indians. They employed wooden sticks with a netted
loop at one end and a ball made of wood or of deerskin
filled with animal hair. As many as a-thousand warriors
in full war paint played on a field several miles long
without sidelines. Games lasted two or three days and
defeat sometimes meant death.
Frenchmen named the game la crosse because the
Indians' sticks reminded them of a crosier, a long staff
resembling a shepherd's crook usually carried by bishops
as a symbol of office. The Indians used the game to
condition their young braves for battle. Often tribal
medicine men served as "game officials."
The Europeans who came to the New World
greatly reduced the number of participants in a contest.
However, they preserved the essential idea of trying to
throw a ball into a goal defended by one's enemies,
while protecting one's own goal from violation. All
throwing and catching was still done with a curved,
netted stick.
The modern game of lacrosse is played on a
rectangular field, 110 yards long and 60 yards wide.
Goals consist of netted six-foot squares 80 yards apart.
Players frequently carry the ball behind the cage to set
up offensive plays, since the goals are positioned 15
yards from the endlines.
Players wear uniforms consisting of helmets with
a metal face mask, hockey-style gloves, arm pads, and
frequently shoulder pads. Football-style jerseys have,
replaced tribal body paint, but the use of black grease
under each eye to ward off the sun's glare recalls the
savage, majestic, boundaryless game played by the
Indians.
Each team consists of three attackmen, three
midfielders, three defensemen, and one goalie. As in
football, a game consists of four 15-minute periods with
a halftime intermission. At the start of each quarter and

moves it into its offensive zone.
Each team must keep four players in the defensive half of the field and three players in its offensive
end. The other three players are free to run from one

In lacrosse, midfielders play for relatively short

while standing in the crease, he must either leave the
circle or pass the ball within four seconds. Once he
leaves the crease, he may not re-enter it until he has
gotten rid of the ball.

Chadbourne's venture might be
considered pop art: representing a popular form in a different context. Country
music is a uniquely American genre
which, at its best, like the blues, can be
genuinely expressive.
Chadbourne
chooses old C&W classics like Roger•
Miller's "Dang Me," Johnny Paycheck's
"Take This Job and chove It," Merle
Haggard's "Swingin' Doors," and Bobby
Bare's "Motel Time Agaut." These songs
dispense their ow r brand of fatalistic
philosophy and rearieck stoicism. They
are the white man's blues--bittersweet
Laments based on recurring themes
and situations (symbols?): women, bars,
motels, hard work, jail, the good life,
escape. They often contain an undercurrent of maudlin humor (sometimes
intentional, sometimes not) which Chadbourne exploits whenever he can through
his vocal style and in frequent instrumental "commentaries" on the vocal in
progress. He translates the frustrations,
struggles, self-chastisements, and pent-up
emotions he's singing about into sounds
and noises on the guitar. The band does
its best to concentrate all the musical
idiosyncrasies of country & western:
instrumental fills or highlights which set
off the vocal line, galloping percussion,
twangy sound, and sparse arrangements.
The sense of humor is never malicious-these guys obviously like country music,
but they're not about to take it seriously.
Chadbourne solves the problem of
how to direct and limit the "freeness" of
free improvisation by using country &
western songs as points of departure and
guiding structures. The results are bizarre
but always entertaining. In any case,
they are just as adventurous as "pure"
improvisation, and definitely a lot more
fun. The Chadbournes' music has proved
to be as popular among straight country
& western fans as among jazz and avantgarde aficionados--quite an accomplishment in itself.

An Insomniac's Guide To Gastritis
BY A. CHAIM SALZBERGER III
NOT BY WALTER HOOK
AND JOE LEVINE
It used to be that the wee hours-that phantom time when the buses don't
run, the mist rolls in, and dwarfish old
men from the Sunpapers are filling all the
newsstands--were only witnessed by certain city employees and consumptive
artistes who could not create at any other
time. The night had an authentic atmosphere because the only people awake
were the mysterious Night People,
who shun the daylight hours.
College has changed all this. Now
swarms of willful insomniacs invade the
night, adulterating the very atmosphere
they hope to find preserved in the odd
corners and back streets of town.
It's too late to turn the tide. We
can't give Manhattan back to the Indians.
Instead we must come to grips with an
important truth; these willful insomniacs
are here to stay, and we often get very
hungry early in the morning.
Take last Tuesday for instance. It
was 1:57 a.m. WaWa's had long since
packed away the last chocolate donut,
and the Scottish fellow at the Grad Club
insisted the counter was closed. There
was nothing at home but a box of ButterBuds and carton of milk from last semester. W hat to do?
I was tired of frozen pizza and

Steward Sandwiches from the all-night
7-11, and I couldn't face Little Tavern.
Putting on my long-johns, I considered
my situation-I needed money, a car,
and company, in that order. Trusty
comrades Walt and Joe were roused from
slumber and quickly enlightened of my
purpose. By 2:30 a.m. we were speeding
through deserted streets in search of
coffee.
First stop: The Open House at
29th and Maryland Avenue. This was a
pleasant surprise, a breakfast and burger
place set in an old one-room stone
building, advertising two to the very

slogans we searched for--"We Never
Close", and (better still) "Breakfast
served anytime".
Beyond these two essential attractions, the Open House offered nothing
more extraordinary than decent coffee at
35 cents, fair pancakes, and subs fea_

turing haddock and crab meat. The
crowd was sleepy and unthreatening--surprisingly few student-types for a place so
close to Mother Hopkins. But, as we
were to learn over the course of our
odyssey, respectable mediocrity can be an
outstanding quality in a night restaurant.
Having shared one plate of hotcakes, one cheeseburger sub (ugh) and a
cup of coffee between the three of us
(the waiter thought we were taking
sacrament together), we were well gassed
up when we headed for the car. The next
stop was Steak'n'Eggs on York Road.
One might ask, as we did, just
what sort of creature a "N'egg" is. We
never found out, but the engima of the
N'eggery operated subtly on our digestion
the whole 20 minutes we were there.
Walt, Joe and I split a ham omlette,
papery home fries, and a foul cup of.
coffee. I wished I'd been more adventurous back home with the Butter Buds.
While we ate, an obese, pallid man in a
black suit and string tie smiled at us. His
grin followed us to the car, and out of the
lot until we passed out of sight. He may
be smiling still.
We headed south on York-Greenmount, destined for Leon's Pig Pen.
Along the road, the row houses grew
increasingly decrepit. The shop windows
looked like prison cells; the buildings,
like post-holocaust bomb shelters. Our
stomachs were gurgling, hoping for more

munchies, when we passed a White Tower
at 27th and Greenmount.
Joe insisted we stop, having a dire
need to relieve himself, so despite my
reservations, we entered. A wall of
staring eyes met us at the door, and all
talking stopped. Apparently the White
Tower was the community's usual
gathering place, for despite the hour, the
place was packed. The customers soon
rqumed their joking and chatting. Of all
the places we visited, this one was the
most alive, its patrons the most good
humored. A tall, leather-jacketed man
was teasing me about my blue sunglasses
when Walter grabbed me by the sleeve
and whispered "Come on." Joe ordered
coffees, to go. We left without tasting the
food, but the coffee was the best we
found that night.

Respectable Ghosts At The Barn
BY JESSICA KUBZANSKY
Attending the Theatre Hopkins
production of Ghosts, by Henrik Ibsen, is
like eating in a favorite medium-priced
restaurant. The food is respectable but
not superb, with a few favorite dishes
that make the place both distinguishable
and special.
When Ghosts was first produced
Ibsen was thought to have opened a can
of dramatic worms, for he made public
that which was, for the Victorian, unspeakably private. Now, although we
cease to be shocked by what are sometimes termed "sexually transmitted diseases," the play is still full of tension and
drama that render the subject of venereal
disease secondary to many other more
fundamental issues.
Ghosts begins slowly—as much
Ibsen's fault as the actors'--as it sets up
and introduces the rest of the dramatic
action. Act I opens, after a brief foreshadowing view of the pivotal characters,
with Mrs. Alving (Virginia Robinson) and
Pastor Manders (Stanley Weiman)conversing. They are discussing plans for an
orphanage which is to be erected in the
late Mr. Alving's honor. During the
course of the conversation, the audience
discovers that things are not what they
seem and that the man to whom the
orphanage is to be dedicated was really a
"depraved profligate" to the day he died.
During some well-executed moments of
dramatic interplay, Mrs. Alving reveals to
Manders that she has sacrificed having her
son with her all these years to avoid a
repetition of his father's decadence; she is
trying to avoid the ghosts that haunt her.
During Act lithe action picks up
and there are further revelations. We find
that the son. Osvald's return home is

caused by his inability to work—something indicative of his illness. "The sins
of the fathers are visited upon the children," Osvald says, and throughout the
play we discover that this is true in a
variety of ways. The past is inescapable.
Ghosts has a number of complex
issues operating throughout, and the
actors, for the most part, do a credible
job with a fairly difficult play.
The performances vary in quality.
Regina, played by Beth Rosner, a senior
at Hopkins, is the most monochromatic
of the actors. Her character is supposed
to be full of "joi de vivre," and as such
she plays her part well--she is full of
energy and bounce. However, her characterization seems contrived at times and is
overdone.
Regina's father Engstrand, a clever, delightful old rogue whose limp and
mannerisms merely complement his deceptive innocence, is beautifully portrayed by Donald Hart. With his convincing accent and physical comportment, he
serves as especially satisfying comic relief.
The leads' performances are char-

,se

acteristic of the quality of the play.
Stanley Weiman's Pastor Manners, though
respectable, is very unsympathetic, true
to lbsens dislike of the clergy. He is a
self-righteously pompous pastor who
blunders through life making a muck of it
because he is bound to the social conventions of the time. Like the play, Weiman
has some superb moments, but at other
times he is unexciting. Weiman is very
fittingly pastor-like, and when he is not
overdoing it, is more than adequate.
Some of Weiman's best moments
come in his interactions and conflicts
with Virginia Robinson. The two wouldbe lovers occasionally hit their stride and
produce some snappy dialogue and
excellent theatre.
Robinson's own performance was
satisfactory. She seems to have a set
repertoire of emotions that she varies
according to the situation. However, aft:
a while, some of her actions become
repetitive and ineffective. Her character's
emancipation from the evil of social
conformity should develop in accordance
with the movement of the play, but by
the third act a little of her freshness has
worn off.
Shaun Greenleafs. rendering of
Osvald Alving begins much better than it
ends. Osvald is a tormented young artist
faced by consequences of actions over
which he has no control, and Greenleafs
portrayal of the sensitive, carefully
controlled young man is excellent.
Greenleaf is well cast, his slight build
accenting his growing frailty.
Where Greenleaf falls short, and in
fact where all of the characters are led
astray, is in the tendency to overact the
most dramatic scenes. Crying on the
stage is difficult to motivate, and if done
too often it becomes maudlin, unbeliev-

Mrs. Alving keeps an eye on her son.
able, and melodramatic. Unfortunately,
most of Act III is a "veil of tears," and
this undermines Osvald's formerly superb
performance as a man tortured by his
heritage.
None of the actors are aided by
their staging; this is one of the weakest
aspects of the whole performance. The
set itself is tasteful, but the blocking is
poor. The actors often have their backs
and profiles to the audience. Admittedly,
the Barn Theatre is badly designed, but
often the actors turn their backs on
purpose. They are (presumably) overcome by emotion or have something to
hide and therefore speak out the window,
away from the audience. Used sparingly,
this device can be very effective; abused
as it is, it becomes intrusive, annoying,
and a cheap theatrical device that can
degenerate into a cop-out for the actor.
Generally, however, Ghosts is a
job well done. It is respectable, though
not superb, and there are some striking
moments. The play is performed sensitively and with a real understanding of
Ibsen's work; the haunting themes of
integrity, the past, the will to live and the
will to die are all expressed, and the
characters are able for the most part to
interact and form a cohesive whole.

A Guerilla Clash
BY TOM GRANT
The bane of any countercultural
genre is popularity, and this same commercial sickness has afflicted the field of
New Wave. New Wave began as a statement of both alienation from an impersonal world and anger at this state of
alienation. Above all, New Wave was a
statement; it transcended the superficiality of the trendy by making a sincere
criticism of the status quo. Additionally,
part of New Wave's ideological appeal
rejection

arose
its
of commercialism—its musicians played in
small clubs rather than catering to the
mainstream norm of sardining a mob of
fans into the largest space possible; also,
New Wave records were produced cheaply, and this combined with a reemergence
of the single allowed a greater number of
new groups the opportunity to break into
the field and produce and record their
own music. Lastly, New Wave has been
characterized by a primal, uncontrollable
energy, ranging from the almost crazed
rock 'n' roll explosions of the Ramones
to the calculated fury of Elvis Costello.
In many ways, the roots of New Wave are
similar to that of rock itself: raw, powerful, but sincere.
Unfortunately, the genre has
succumbed to the wiles of the record
industry. New Wave has become fashionable, which has emasculated its purpose
and caused its decay. People who derided
the field four years ago are now proclaiming themselves as what they believe to
be "punks", but what they are really
doing is listening to "Rock Lobster"
while wearing bizarre sunglasses. Not
only has New Wave been misinterpreted
and trivialized, but markedly inferior
groups such as Blondie and the B-52's
(who can hardly be seen as anything but a
new style of party music) have overshadowed the genuine New Wave artists.
But the Clash still has its finger on the,
adrenalin-fired pulse of New Wave, and
the popularity which it has experienced
since London Calling has not tempted it

into complete self-indulgence or sophomoricism. As.opposed to some groups
(such as the Sex Pistols) who.have taken
wild punches at the world, the scorn of
The Clash is more refined: its members
know not only how hard to strike, but
where society's weak points are. Much of
the discontent of John Leyden and his
kin has been unrestrained fury (snarling,
screaming, bashing, and spitting), but The
Clash has been more successful in its
attacks because of its artful calculation
and incisive criticism. This was not
readily apparent on The Clash's first
album, but Sandinista!, the group's
newest release, combines this craftful
criticism with a dash of innovation. Like
Elvis Costello and the Attractions, The
Clash has matured since its first efforts,
but unlike Costello its members have
broken away from the derivative R&B
sound of New Wave. Sandinista! is a
myriad of sounds and styles, ranging from
the reggae beat of "Living in Fame" to
the slick American jazz flavor of "Look
Here". Sandinista! is full of experimentation:
the background against which
"Ivan Meets G.I. Joe" is played is a
cacophony of the familiar bangs, whistles,
crashes and explosions of arcade video
games; "Mensforth Hill" and "Silicon on
Sapphire" are bizarre amalgamations of
synthesizer effects, spoken dialogue, and
distorted music reminiscent of "Revolution No. 9".
For an English group, the Clash
deals with surprisingly American subject
matter. The best example of this is "The
Call-Up," a pointed anti-draft statement.
("It's up to you not to heed the call-up/
You must not ask the way you were
brought up... All the young people from
down the ages/ Gladly marched off to
die.") Although this isn't quite Hemingway or Heller commenting on the terrible
nature of war, "The Call-Up" stands far
above the rest of "mainstream" New
Wave in both maturity and strength. The
same can be said of "The Magnificent
Seven," a collage of images portraying a
mad post-industrial Western world over
which we have no control. "The Leader"

the NCAA's as "three times as

best sabre fencer in Stevens

made it higher than eighth,"
Oles said. "The best we've ever
had was Cordts (two-time MAC
sabre champ and former Blue
Jay co-captain Paul Cordts) two
years ago, when he came in
sixth.
To do well requires
umpteen years of experience,
which most of our guys don't
have, or a far more intense
physical regimen than our guys

can handle with the high grade
pressures here."
Oles said it is "within the
realm of possibility" that either
Hsieh or Mihalsky could make it
to the final round of the NCAA
tournament, but that was his
most optimistic statement. However, their teammates have high
hopes for the two fencers.

under pressure, and recently

unexpected. He had been considered the number-five sabre

season, but worked his way to a
starting spot.

Table Tennis At JHU
What started as a win for
Amr-Yehia Eissa has begun to
look like another potential varsity sport for Hopkins. Eissa,
playing as a freshman two years
ago, took the BIA table tennis
tournament handily. Surprised
at the number of people interested in playing the sport, Eissa was
determined to seek out members
and form a club or a team.
The team came first.
Captained by Eissa and Charlie
Kruarsky, it played several
matches in the 1980 season,
culminating in the East Regional
table tennis tournament three
weeks ago. The Hopkins team
placed fifth out of twenty
schools, without the help of two
of the fol members. Table
tennis, unlike its American bastardization, ping-pong, is a sport
of skill and determination.
Teams consist of four men each,
a doubles team and two singles.
The JHU squad consists of two
teams, an A and a B, which can
represent the school at tournaments.
The team struggled to gain
recognition from the Athletic
Center, but a massive campaign

by members to show the interest
of the students finally broke the
resolve of the staff, which
has managed to throw some
support behind them. In fact,
athletic director Bob Scott has
even considered the purchase of
a new table for the team, a move
which would add to its practice
facilities.
If the idea of having a coach
in table tennis sounds a bit odd,
consider the fact that schools
such as George Washington,
UMBC, and Catorsville Community College all have recognized squads with coaches. Eissa
hopes that the Hopkins group
can play some matches between
these schools, and indeed even
practice with them on a somewhat regular basis.
Eissa and Kruarsky are no
slackers themselves, each being
ranked in .the U.S. and Eissa
being ranked in the top 300 here
and Southeast Asia.
The team is also hoping to
start an SAC-approved club, and
all campus members wanting to
join or expressing any interest in
the club are urged to call Eissa
or Kruarsky.

thoughts and encouragement

An Oddly Human Document
What are intentions worth?
The Judicial Code is an oddly human
document: it is full of contradictions,
flaws, and outright blunders; it has, underneath its semantic problems, a very wellintentioned drive to create some workable
system; and most important, its strengths
and weaknesses came from an ongoing
process of change.
Among its many shortcomings:
The people involved in a case can't
bring a lawyer with them when they appear
to argue the case. This guarantees a superior position for the University,which retains
its right to a lawyer.
The boundaries of "sexual misconduct" are left undefined. We're all out of
here, pronto, if someone gets conservative
with this one. Why not just say rape,
assault, and flashing?
The Student Council, which would
choose Judicial Board members and exercise veto power, would maintain de facto
control over the board. A fair board is an
independent board. Obviously, someone
has to hold elections to begin with, but
after that, a Judicial Board runs its own
shop.
Improvements to the Code can only
come as amendents. There is no way to
revise the Code's many examples of vague

language before it undergoes a review--in
the fall of 1985.
And so on. But beyond its problems
lies a very basic plus: we finally have a
document that provides for due process.
The acid test, then:- So what if we
don't have a Judicial Code?
Eventually, we should work out a
method of stopping the arbitrary way discipline is meted out. The Judicial Code gives
students a say in the works, which is
lacking today. We believe, then, that
passing the document and then working on
its flaws is better than simply killing the
Code.
Mike Steele's opinion is that the
Code cannot be revised, and presented for a
second vote, and presented to the Board of
Trustees before the year is out should the
Code be defeated Tuesday. Why not work
around the red tape by passing the Code
and continuing to work on it?
Tuesday is a red herring. The
election's "yes" or "no" is not a simple
rubber stamp about the Code so we can
stop thinking about it. Whether or not the
Code passes is not nearly as important as
whether it continues to be improved. It is
a complex, flawed, worthy idea which
needs ongoing whittling and fixing.
Intentions, after all, are everything.

Draft Of The Johns Hopkins University
Undergraduate Judicial Code

I. PREAMBLE
It is the intention of the undergraduate students of the School of Arts and
Sciences and the G.W.C. Whiting School of Engineering of The Johns Hopkins
University to create and maintain a judicial code. The judicial code is intended
to provide members of the academic community with a forum for airing and
resolving their grievances against students.

II. JURISDICTION
This code applies to the undergraduates of the School of Arts and Sciences
and the G.W.C. Whiting School of Engineering of The Johns Hopkins University.
This code pertains to offenses committed on University property, off University
property but against members of the University community, and off campus
criminal offenses allegedly committed by a student. A member of the University
community shall be defined as either a full or part-time student registered in
the Univeristy or an employee of the Univerisity.
Disciplinary action concerning alleged misconduct involving the possession
or use of firearms or explosive substances on campus or their illegal possession
off campus, sale of illegal drugs, arson, or violent conduct that has seriously
threatened the life or safety of another person, as well as allegations of_gudent
misconduct during the summer months, shall be the sole responsibility of the
Dean of the Homewood Faculties or his designee.
The judicial code is to be in effect during the spring and fall academic
semesters as well as the intersession mini-semester and is to be jointly
administered by the Judicial Board of the Student Council and the Director of
Student Services [herinafter "Director"1. The Judicial Code provides the sole
Univeristy forums for airing disputes over which the Code has jurisdiction.
III. PROCEDURE
A. Procedure for certifying a charge:
1. Any person who believes that conduct warranting disciplinary action
has been committed by a student may file a written complaint
against the student with the Director of Student Activities, or his
designess.
2. A written complaint must be submitted within either:
a. fifteen (15) calendar days from the date of the commission of the
alleged offense, or
b. Fifteen (15) calendar days from the date of discovery of the
alleged offense or the identity of the offender.
3. The complaint must contain the following informationa. name and address of the complainant
b. name of the student(s) charged with misconduct
c. a specific and factual statement of the misconduct, including a
description of the damage or injury.
4. The Director shall mail or deliver notification to a student against
whom a charge has been made within three (3)calendar days
following the date of receipt of the complaint.
5. Notice must be served by either:
a. hand delivery, or
b. certified mail, return receipt requested.
6. Notice shall containa. a copy of the complaint including the name of the complainant;
b. copies of documentary evidence supporting the charge, if any. If
any new documentary evidence is obtained after notice is served
but prior to the hearing, a copy shall be given promptly to the
student charged, but no less than 72 hours before the hearing;
c. a copy of the judicial code;
d. notice that all parties have a right to an advisor who is a member
. of the University community to assist in the preparation of the
case, but an attorney may not represent either the complainant
or the student charged in proceedings under this Code;
e. time, date and place of a scheduled hearing to consider the
complaint.
7. Objections to jurisdiction over offenses may be submitted to the
Director. If the Director determines the offense is not one which
falls within the code's jurisdiction he shall terminate the matter and
inform both parties.
8. The Judicial Board shall maintain a log of complaints, chronologically numbered but lacking personal identifying information, with
information as to whether the conduct giving rise to the complaint
was considered as within the ambit of this code and the jurisdiction
of the Judicial Board.
9. The accused shall have the option to have his case heard before the
Judicial Board or the Director. If the student charged selects the
Judicial Board to hear his case, the Director shall convene the board.
IV. PROCEDURE FOR HEARING THE CASE BEFORE THE DIRECTOR
A. If the student charged selects the Director to hear the case, then the
following procedures shall be followed1 The hearing shall be closed unless the accused files a written request
for a public hearing with the Director. In cases of sexual misconduct the hearing shall be closed unless the accused files a written
request for a public hearing with the Director and the complainant
makes no objection. The complainant shall be notified as to
whether a hearing is to be closed or open.
2. All hearings shall be taped and both parties will be given access to
the tape upon request.
3. At the commencement of a hearing the Director shall read the
charges after which time the student shall indicate whether he
admits or denies the charge.
4. The Director shall receive all evidence and hear all testimony of the
parties and the witnesses at a hearing at which the complainant shall

first present his complaint and supporting evidence. Thereafter,
the student charged shall be given an opportunity to rebut the complaint or present evidence of mitigating circumstances.
The Director and the parties shall have the opportunity to question
all witnesses.
The Director shall render a decision after hearing all evidence offered
by the parties.
The Director shall notify the parties of his decision either:
a. At the close of the hearing, to be subsequently confirmed in
writing, or
b. By letter within 7 calendar days following the date of the hearing.
The Director shall notify the Dean of Academic Services of the
verdict.
The Director may recommend sanctions tothe Dean of Academic
Services.

V. PROCEDURE FOR CASES BEFORE THE JUDICIAL BOARD
A. The membership of the Board
1. Nine members will be selected by the Student Council, normally
during the previous academic year, according to the selection process
for the Student Council committees. Members shall serve one year
and may be reappointed.
2. The Student Council shall select students to fill vacancies on the
Board according to V.A.1.
3. The Board shall select a chairperson from among its members.
B. Composition of the Hearing Panel
1. The Chair shall prepare a list of Judicial Board members at the
beginning of the academic year.
2. A Hearing Panel shall be convened by selecting the first three names
on the list. The Presiding Official shall be the next person onthe list.
Every member of the Panel, including the Presiding Official, should
be free of bias or personal interest in the matter.
a. A member of the Panel, the student charged, or the complainant
may challenge the impartiality of a member.
b. The Panel shall hear the charges of bias and must decide whether
the voting member whould retain his seat. A majority of voting
members of the panel may remove a fellow member on the basis
of bias. The member challenged shall recuse himself from voting
on his disqualification. The Presiding Officer shall vote on the
question of bias. A new member shall be appointed to replace a
disqualified member.
3. The Presiding Official is to perform the following duties:
a. attend all Hearing Panel hearings
b. maintain all Judicial Board records and deliver the same to the
office of the General Counsel when not in use by the Judicial
Board.
c. vote only in the absence of a Panel member.
4. A member of the Judicial Board may be removed for dereliction of
duty by an affirmative vote of 6 members of the Judicial Board or
by a 2/3 vote of the Student Council.
5. A new Panel, consisting of the following six names will be convened
for each case.
C. Procedures for the Hearing Panel
1. The hearing shall be closed unless the accused files a written request
for a public hearing with the Director. In cases of sexual misconduct the hearing shall be closed unless the acccused files a written
request for a public hearing with the Director and the complainant
makes no objection. The complainant must be notified as to
whether a hearing is to be open or closed.
2. A.. hearings shall be taped and a party will be given access to the
tape upon request.
3. Security of the documentary evidence and any reports of the Hearing Panel shall be the responsibility of the Presiding Official or
his/her designee. The materials are to be kept in the Office of the
General Counsel.
4. The Presiding Official shall read the charges at the commencement
of the hearing and the student charged shall indicate whether he
admits or denies the charge.
5. The Panel shall receive all evidence and hear all testimony of the
parties and their witnesses at a hearing. The complainant shall first
present his complaint and supporting evidence and the student
charged shall then be given an opportunity to rebut the complaint
or present evidence of mitigating circumstances.
6. Panel members and the parties shall have the opportunity to
examine all the witnesses.
7. Members of the Hearing Panel shall not discuss the cases with persons not on the Panel.
8. The student charged may be found guilty by a unanimous vote. The
verdict shall be accompanied by a written opinion stating the basis
for the decision reached by the Panel and any dissenting opinion.
The entire record shall be forwarded to the Dean of Academic
Services.
VI. SANCTIONS
A. The Dean of Academic Services is responsible for determining and
implementing the sanction and shall meet with the student to be
disciplined before choosing a sanction. All sanctions shall reflect the
severity of the offense. The Dean is urged to take into consideration
the sanctions recommended by the Hearing Panel or the Director of
Student Activities.

student of his decision in writing.

Dean of Academic Services.

be preserved in the office of the General Counsel until the expiration of the applicable statute of limitations, after which they shall
be destroyed.
2. The Judicial Board shall maintain a summary of all cases brought
before it. The summaries shall contain the following information
only:
a. the charge;
b. the verdict;

Amendments to this Judicial Code shall be approved by a three quarters

A. This code shall become effective September 1,1981 and shall remain in

Student Council and the Dean of Academic Services and a report shall
be presented to the Student Council no later than the beginning of the
spring semester, 1986.
XI. REORGANIZATION OF HOMEWOOD FACULTIES
In the event of a reorganization of the administration of the Homewood
faculties the references to any particular University academic or administrative office or officer shall be construed as referring to a successor office or
officer as bearing equivalent or substantially similar responsibilities, to be
determined by the chief academic officer of the University.
XII. STANDING OF THE JUDICIAL BOARD
The Judicial Board is an independent committee of the Student Council.
The Student Council may not interfere with the activities or decisions of
the Judicial Board.
XIII.FAILURE TO ABIDE BY CODE PROCEDURES
A failure to abide by the procedures established by this Code shall constitute a basis for an appeal.

Hopkins has lacrosse and the official Lacrosse Hall of
Fame on its campus.
The 35 national lacrosse championships won by
the Blue Jays demonstrate their domination of the sport.
Twice lacrosse has been played in the Olympics (1928
and 1932) and each time the U.S. representative was
Johns Hopkins. Moreover, one quarter of those inducted into the Lacrosse Hall of Fame have been associated with Hopkins.
For Blue Jay sports fans, THE SEASON has
arrived. Pavlov would have felt at home at Hopkins,
since any Hoppie worth his weight in GPA points has
been conditioned to flee the confines of the Eisenhower
library for the excitement of Homewood Field. On a
typical Saturday afternoon in the spring, enough Hopkins students descend upon the Conrad Geblein stands
to make the untrained observer think that Organic and
Occ. Civ. review sessions are now being taught outside.
When the Blue Jays defeated Maryland to win
the NCAA championship in 1974 and 1979, the Hopkins
rooters sang "Amen"--presumably to mock the Terrapin
fans who traditionally sing it in victory. Lacrosse
disciples know better, however. They are convinced that
it was done to show that lacrosse is akin to religion at
Hopkins!
At Johns Hopkins, which considers itself the
center of the lacrosse world, national titles are expected
by everyone. Blue Jay coaches do not celebrate when
they win a championship; instead they breathe a sigh of
relief.
According to athletic director Bob Scott,
"Lacrosse is a fast-moving and exciting sport. The
wide-open action presents many scoring opportunities
during the course of a game. Fifteen to twenty-five
goals are commonly scored, and in my view lacrosse
contains the best elements of football, basketball,
soccer, and hockey."
The fastest game on two feet (hockey is played
on skates), lacrosse is an exciting and invigorating game
which is fun to watch and to play. At its best, the sport
combines the body contact of Stanley Cup hockey with
the agility, grace, and quickness of NBA basketball.

Bob Ott, a former star midfielder at Maryland,
called lacrosse "a jumble of all games. I enjoy the
violence like football. There is plenty of free running
like soccer. The play around the goal is much like
basketball, and the stick makes it like hockey."
Lacrosse was invented by North American
Indians. They employed wooden sticks with a netted
loop at one end and a ball made of wood or of deerskin
filled with animal hair. As many as a-thousand warriors
in full war paint played on a field several miles long
without sidelines. Games lasted two or three days and
defeat sometimes meant death.
Frenchmen named the game la crosse because the
Indians' sticks reminded them of a crosier, a long staff
resembling a shepherd's crook usually carried by bishops
as a symbol of office. The Indians used the game to
condition their young braves for battle. Often tribal
medicine men served as "game officials."
The Europeans who came to the New World
greatly reduced the number of participants in a contest.
However, they preserved the essential idea of trying to
throw a ball into a goal defended by one's enemies,
while protecting one's own goal from violation. All
throwing and catching was still done with a curved,
netted stick.
The modern game of lacrosse is played on a
rectangular field, 110 yards long and 60 yards wide.
Goals consist of netted six-foot squares 80 yards apart.
Players frequently carry the ball behind the cage to set
up offensive plays, since the goals are positioned 15
yards from the endlines.
Players wear uniforms consisting of helmets with
a metal face mask, hockey-style gloves, arm pads, and
frequently shoulder pads. Football-style jerseys have,
replaced tribal body paint, but the use of black grease
under each eye to ward off the sun's glare recalls the
savage, majestic, boundaryless game played by the
Indians.
Each team consists of three attackmen, three
midfielders, three defensemen, and one goalie. As in
football, a game consists of four 15-minute periods with
a halftime intermission. At the start of each quarter and

There are two main classes of infractions in adept at shooting and passing.
lacrosse: technical fouls such as offsides and personal
fouls such as slashing or tripping. Penalties range from
loss of possession to ejection of a player from the game.
Most penalties are for 30 seconds or one minute.
As in hockey, the offending player must remain
in a "penalty box" and his team plays a man short until
either a goal has been scored, the penalty time has
elapsed, or his team gains possession of the ball and
moves it into its offensive zone.
Each team must keep four players in the defensive half of the field and three players in its offensive
end. The other three players are free to run from one
end of the playing surface to the other.
In lacrosse, midfielders play for relatively short
periods of time and frequently change on the fly in the
manner of ice hockey "lines." As in football, there is
free substitution when the referee blows his whistle.
Normally, the ball is turned over to the opposing
team when a player throws it out of bounds or crosses
the sideline when the ball is in his possession. On a
missed shot at the goal, however, the team closest to the
ball when it goes out of bounds is awarded possession.
The circled area around each goal is called the
"crease" and it may be occupied only by a goalie or
defenseman. Attacking players may not step into this
area. When a defensive player gains control of the ball
while standing in the crease, he must either leave the
circle or pass the ball within four seconds. Once he
leaves the crease, he may not re-enter it until he has
gotten rid of the ball.
A newcomer to the sport will quickly notice that
players use sticks of varying lengths and sizes. They may
vary from 40 to 72 inches in length and be from seven to
12 inches wide at the top.
Attackmen and midfielders employ smaller sticks
to protect the ball from opponents and to ensure maximum maneuverability, while defensemen use longer,

Laments based on recurring themes

progress. He translates the frustrations,
struggles, self-chastisements, and pent-up
emotions he's singing about into sounds
and noises on the guitar. The band does
its best to concentrate all the musical
idiosyncrasies of country & western:
instrumental fills or highlights which set
off the vocal line, galloping percussion,
twangy sound, and sparse arrangements.
The sense of humor is never malicious-these guys obviously like country music,
but they're not about to take it seriously.
Chadbourne solves the problem of
how to direct and limit the "freeness" of
free improvisation by using country &
western songs as points of departure and
guiding structures. The results are bizarre
but always entertaining. In any case,
they are just as adventurous as "pure"
improvisation, and definitely a lot more
fun. The Chadbournes' music has proved
to be as popular among straight country
& western fans as among jazz and avantgarde aficionados--quite an accomplishment in itself.

It used to be that the wee hours-that phantom time when the buses don't
run, the mist rolls in, and dwarfish old
men from the Sunpapers are filling all the
newsstands--were only witnessed by certain city employees and consumptive
artistes who could not create at any other
time. The night had an authentic atmosphere because the only people awake
were the mysterious Night People,
who shun the daylight hours.
College has changed all this. Now
swarms of willful insomniacs invade the
night, adulterating the very atmosphere
they hope to find preserved in the odd
corners and back streets of town.
It's too late to turn the tide. We
can't give Manhattan back to the Indians.
Instead we must come to grips with an
important truth; these willful insomniacs
are here to stay, and we often get very
hungry early in the morning.
Take last Tuesday for instance. It
was 1:57 a.m. WaWa's had long since
packed away the last chocolate donut,
and the Scottish fellow at the Grad Club
insisted the counter was closed. There
was nothing at home but a box of ButterBuds and carton of milk from last semester. W hat to do?
I was tired of frozen pizza and

Steward Sandwiches from the all-night
7-11, and I couldn't face Little Tavern.
Putting on my long-johns, I considered
my situation-I needed money, a car,
and company, in that order. Trusty
comrades Walt and Joe were roused from
slumber and quickly enlightened of my
purpose. By 2:30 a.m. we were speeding
through deserted streets in search of
coffee.
First stop: The Open House at
29th and Maryland Avenue. This was a
pleasant surprise, a breakfast and burger
place set in an old one-room stone
building, advertising two to the very

slogans we searched for--"We Never
Close", and (better still) "Breakfast
served anytime".
Beyond these two essential attractions, the Open House offered nothing
more extraordinary than decent coffee at
35 cents, fair pancakes, and subs fea_

turing haddock and crab meat. The
crowd was sleepy and unthreatening--surprisingly few student-types for a place so
close to Mother Hopkins. But, as we
were to learn over the course of our
odyssey, respectable mediocrity can be an
outstanding quality in a night restaurant.
Having shared one plate of hotcakes, one cheeseburger sub (ugh) and a

sacrament together), we were well gassed

While we ate, an obese, pallid man in a
black suit and string tie smiled at us. His
grin followed us to the car, and out of the
lot until we passed out of sight. He may
be smiling still.
We headed south on York-Greenmount, destined for Leon's Pig Pen.
Along the road, the row houses grew
increasingly decrepit. The shop windows
looked like prison cells; the buildings,
like post-holocaust bomb shelters. Our
stomachs were gurgling, hoping for more

munchies, when we passed a White Tower
at 27th and Greenmount.
Joe insisted we stop, having a dire
need to relieve himself, so despite my
reservations, we entered. A wall of
staring eyes met us at the door, and all
talking stopped. Apparently the White
Tower was the community's usual
gathering place, for despite the hour, the
place was packed. The customers soon
rqumed their joking and chatting. Of all
the places we visited, this one was the
most alive, its patrons the most good
humored. A tall, leather-jacketed man
was teasing me about my blue sunglasses
when Walter grabbed me by the sleeve
and whispered "Come on." Joe ordered
coffees, to go. We left without tasting the
food, but the coffee was the best we
found that night.

Respectable Ghosts At The Barn
BY JESSICA KUBZANSKY
Attending the Theatre Hopkins
production of Ghosts, by Henrik Ibsen, is
like eating in a favorite medium-priced
restaurant. The food is respectable but
not superb, with a few favorite dishes
that make the place both distinguishable
and special.
When Ghosts was first produced
Ibsen was thought to have opened a can
of dramatic worms, for he made public
that which was, for the Victorian, unspeakably private. Now, although we
cease to be shocked by what are sometimes termed "sexually transmitted diseases," the play is still full of tension and
drama that render the subject of venereal
disease secondary to many other more
fundamental issues.
Ghosts begins slowly—as much
Ibsen's fault as the actors'--as it sets up
and introduces the rest of the dramatic
action. Act I opens, after a brief foreshadowing view of the pivotal characters,
with Mrs. Alving (Virginia Robinson) and
Pastor Manders (Stanley Weiman)conversing. They are discussing plans for an
orphanage which is to be erected in the
late Mr. Alving's honor. During the
course of the conversation, the audience
discovers that things are not what they
seem and that the man to whom the
orphanage is to be dedicated was really a
"depraved profligate" to the day he died.
During some well-executed moments of
dramatic interplay, Mrs. Alving reveals to
Manders that she has sacrificed having her
son with her all these years to avoid a
repetition of his father's decadence; she is
trying to avoid the ghosts that haunt her.
During Act lithe action picks up
and there are further revelations. We find
that the son. Osvald's return home is

caused by his inability to work—something indicative of his illness. "The sins
of the fathers are visited upon the children," Osvald says, and throughout the
play we discover that this is true in a
variety of ways. The past is inescapable.
Ghosts has a number of complex
issues operating throughout, and the
actors, for the most part, do a credible
job with a fairly difficult play.
The performances vary in quality.
Regina, played by Beth Rosner, a senior
at Hopkins, is the most monochromatic
of the actors. Her character is supposed
to be full of "joi de vivre," and as such
she plays her part well--she is full of
energy and bounce. However, her characterization seems contrived at times and is
overdone.
Regina's father Engstrand, a clever, delightful old rogue whose limp and
mannerisms merely complement his deceptive innocence, is beautifully portrayed by Donald Hart. With his convincing accent and physical comportment, he
serves as especially satisfying comic relief.
The leads' performances are char-

,se

acteristic of the quality of the play.
Stanley Weiman's Pastor Manners, though
respectable, is very unsympathetic, true
to lbsens dislike of the clergy. He is a
self-righteously pompous pastor who
blunders through life making a muck of it
because he is bound to the social conventions of the time. Like the play, Weiman
has some superb moments, but at other
times he is unexciting. Weiman is very
fittingly pastor-like, and when he is not
overdoing it, is more than adequate.
Some of Weiman's best moments
come in his interactions and conflicts
with Virginia Robinson. The two wouldbe lovers occasionally hit their stride and
produce some snappy dialogue and
excellent theatre.
Robinson's own performance was
satisfactory. She seems to have a set
repertoire of emotions that she varies
according to the situation. However, aft:
a while, some of her actions become
repetitive and ineffective. Her character's
emancipation from the evil of social
conformity should develop in accordance
with the movement of the play, but by
the third act a little of her freshness has
worn off.
Shaun Greenleafs. rendering of
Osvald Alving begins much better than it
ends. Osvald is a tormented young artist
faced by consequences of actions over
which he has no control, and Greenleafs

most of Act III is a "veil of tears," and

The bane of any countercultural
genre is popularity, and this same commercial sickness has afflicted the field of
New Wave. New Wave began as a statement of both alienation from an impersonal world and anger at this state of
alienation. Above all, New Wave was a
statement; it transcended the superficiality of the trendy by making a sincere
criticism of the status quo. Additionally,
part of New Wave's ideological appeal

New Wave records were produced cheaply, and this combined with a reemergence
of the single allowed a greater number of
new groups the opportunity to break into
the field and produce and record their
own music. Lastly, New Wave has been
characterized by a primal, uncontrollable
energy, ranging from the almost crazed
rock 'n' roll explosions of the Ramones
to the calculated fury of Elvis Costello.
In many ways, the roots of New Wave are
similar to that of rock itself: raw, powerful, but sincere.
Unfortunately, the genre has
succumbed to the wiles of the record
industry. New Wave has become fashionable, which has emasculated its purpose
and caused its decay. People who derided
the field four years ago are now proclaiming themselves as what they believe to
be "punks", but what they are really
doing is listening to "Rock Lobster"
while wearing bizarre sunglasses. Not
only has New Wave been misinterpreted
and trivialized, but markedly inferior
groups such as Blondie and the B-52's
(who can hardly be seen as anything but a
new style of party music) have overshadowed the genuine New Wave artists.
But the Clash still has its finger on the,
adrenalin-fired pulse of New Wave, and

wild punches at the world, the scorn of

Table Tennis At JHU
What started as a win for
Amr-Yehia Eissa has begun to
look like another potential varsity sport for Hopkins. Eissa,
playing as a freshman two years
ago, took the BIA table tennis
tournament handily. Surprised
at the number of people interested in playing the sport, Eissa was
determined to seek out members
and form a club or a team.
The team came first.
Captained by Eissa and Charlie
Kruarsky, it played several
matches in the 1980 season,
culminating in the East Regional
table tennis tournament three
weeks ago. The Hopkins team
placed fifth out of twenty
schools, without the help of two
of the fol members. Table
tennis, unlike its American bastardization, ping-pong, is a sport
of skill and determination.
Teams consist of four men each,
a doubles team and two singles.
The JHU squad consists of two
teams, an A and a B, which can
represent the school at tournaments.
The team struggled to gain
recognition from the Athletic
Center, but a massive campaign

by members to show the interest
of the students finally broke the
resolve of the staff, which
has managed to throw some
support behind them. In fact,
athletic director Bob Scott has
even considered the purchase of
a new table for the team, a move
which would add to its practice
facilities.
If the idea of having a coach
in table tennis sounds a bit odd,
consider the fact that schools
such as George Washington,
UMBC, and Catorsville Community College all have recognized squads with coaches. Eissa
hopes that the Hopkins group
can play some matches between
these schools, and indeed even
practice with them on a somewhat regular basis.
Eissa and Kruarsky are no
slackers themselves, each being
ranked in .the U.S. and Eissa
being ranked in the top 300 here
and Southeast Asia.
The team is also hoping to
start an SAC-approved club, and
all campus members wanting to
join or expressing any interest in
the club are urged to call Eissa
or Kruarsky.
